description: A point of interest or "POI" is represented by a point or "node" on the map and has geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude). A POI can be a standalone node or it can be part of a "way" (an ordered list of nodes representing a linear feature or area).
howToMap: Add a point of interest using Places Editor's "Point" tool to create a point on the map and select the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu.
featureTypes:
Places supports a wide variety of POIs, a full list of which can be found in our preset spreadsheet (NPS-only). This guide is intended to serve as a "starter kit" for contributing to Places and is intentionally not comprehensive, including only the basic and most common POI types. Don't see the feature you're looking for? Send us an email or open an issue on GitHub.

The following are the priority POI types for the NPS.gov Centennial redesign, which will drive individual park pages on the new site:

  • Visitor Centers
  • Entrance Stations
  • Campgrounds
  • Park Districts
  • Trailheads
name: Points of Interest

subtypes.description: A visitor center is a building housing information for visitors, typically including some or all of the following: information resources, facilities (e.g. restrooms, drinking water), ranger staff, and exhibits.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a visitor center by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Visitor Center" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
subtypes.name: Visitor Center

subtypes.description: An entrance station is an official entry point into a park.
subtypes.howToMap: Add an entrance station by creating a point on top of the entrance and selecting "Entrance Station" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Entrance Station

subtypes.description: A campground is an area, usually divided into a number of pitches (or "campsites"), where people can camp overnight using tents or camper vans or caravans.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a campground by creating a point in the middle of the area and selecting "Campground" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Campground

subtypes.description: A park district or "locality" is, generally speaking, a region of a park that has a name. This can come in a variety of forms including an official park administrative unit, a named region of a park, or a city/town neighborhood.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a park district by creating a point in the middle of the associated area and selecting "Park District" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Park District

subtypes.description: A trailhead is the point at which a trail begins, where the trail is often intended for hiking, biking, skiing, snowshoeing, snowmobiling, horseback riding, or off-road vehicles.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a trailhead by creating a point at the start of the trail and selecting "Trailhead" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.approvedUsesDescription: If the trail is intended for specific uses, add the appropriate "Approved Use" using the "Approved Uses" form in the "Edit feature" menu:
subtypes.name: Trailhead

subtypes.description: A ranger station is a building or facility primarily intended to house park law enforcement and rescue staff, and is typically not open to the public. It can also be as simple as a ranger sitting at a campground kiosk. Ranger stations can be seasonal, and they are commonly confused with visitor centers as both can be located in the same building.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a ranger station by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Ranger Station" from the "Select feature type" menu. In the event the station is co-located with a visitor center, the best practice is to create two coincident points - one for the station and another for the VC. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
subtypes.name: Ranger Station

subtypes.description: Headquarters is a park's official headquarters.
subtypes.howToMap: Add park headquarters by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Headquarters" from the "Select feature type" menu. In the event the office is co-located with a visitor center, create two coincident points - one for the headquarters and another for the VC. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
subtypes.name: Headquarters

subtypes.description: A restroom is a restroom facility or "toilet" open to the public.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a restroom by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Restroom" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
subtypes.name: Restroom

subtypes.description: Information is an information source for visitors, typically an informational board. This is the default and most basic information-related tag, which can be added in more specific forms such as an information map.
subtypes.howToMap: Add information by creating a point on top of the amenity and selecting "Information" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Information

subtypes.description: A campsite is an individual pitch within a campground where people can camp overnight using tents or camper vans or caravans.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a campsite by creating a point in the middle of the pitch and selecting "Campsite" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Campsite

subtypes.description: A picnic area is an area that is suitable for outdoors eating and may have a number of facilities to aid a picnic: tables, benches, restrooms, grills, water taps, covered pavilions, etc. Or, it may just be a grassy area popular for picnics.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a picnic area by creating a point in the middle of the area and selecting "Picnic Area" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Picnic Area

subtypes.description: A lodge or "alpine hut" is a remote building located in the mountains intended to provide board and lodging.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a lodge by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Lodge" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
subtypes.name: Lodge

subtypes.description: A store is a general store, typically selling things like tools, building supplies, clothes, food, and similar items.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a store by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Store" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
subtypes.name: Store

subtypes.description: Food service is also commonly referred to as a food court. It is typically an indoor area within a facility that houses multiple food vendors and provides a common area for dining.
subtypes.howToMap: Add food service by creating a point on top of the associated building and selecting "Food Service" from the "Select feature type" menu. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
subtypes.name: Food Service

subtypes.description: A litter receptacle is a single small container for depositing garbage that is easily accesible for pedestrians. Similar expressions: trash can, garbage can, waste basket, rubbish bin, litter bin.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a litter receptacle by creating a point on top of the container and selecting "Litter Receptacle" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Litter Receptacle

subtypes.description: A telephone is a phone available for public use, typically a pay phone on a stand or wall. It may be indoors or outdoors.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a telephone by creating a point on top of the telephone and selecting "Telephone" from the "Select feature type" menu. Where several telephones are arranged side by side, arrange several similar points side by side.
subtypes.name: Telephone

subtypes.description: Potable water is a location at which potable water is available for consumption. Typically this comes in the form of a water fountain.
subtypes.howToMap: Add potable water by creating a point on top of the amenity and selecting "Potable Water" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Potable Water

subtypes.description: A gas station is a facility where vehicles can be refueled.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a gas station by creating a point on top of it and selecting "Gas Station" from the "Select feature type" menu. If the gas station includes a building housing a store, see the store section above to learn how to add it. Additionally, trace the building footprint if it has not been added (see the buildings section to learn more about tracing building footprints).
subtypes.name: Gas Station

subtypes.description: A boat launch is a ramp into the water used to launch a boat, also referred to as a slipway, boat ramp, or boat landing.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a boat launch by creating a point in the middle of the ramp and selecting "Boat Launch" from the "Select feature type" menu.
subtypes.approvedUsesDescription: If the boat launch is intended for specific uses, add the appropriate "Approved Use" using the "Approved Water Uses" form in the "Edit feature" menu. Use "Canoe" for non-motorized watercraft and "Motorboat" for motorized watercraft. Learn more about water trails in the trail section here.
subtypes.name: Boat Launch

description: Buildings in Places are intentionally simple. We are primarily concerned with building footprints, while any additional building amenities are added as points of interest on top of the footprint (see the points of interest section to learn more).
howToMap: Add a building footprint by using the "Area" tool to trace the building footprint and select "Building" from the "Select feature type" menu:
furtherDescription:
• (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Address
  • Levels

Additionally, if you know the location of the building's entrance or exit you can add it as a vertex on the building footprint polygon. Add a building entrance/exit by creating a point at the appropriate location and selecting "Entrance/Exit" from the "Select feature type" menu.

  • (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
name: Buildings

description: A road is a way intended primarily for passage of motorized vehicles.
howToMap: Add a road by using the "Line" tool to trace its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu. If a road's classification is unknown, default to the "Unknown Road" preset.
featureTypes: Places supports a variety of road classifications, outlined below. Basic road structures, attributes, and topology best practices are also outlined here including adding a bridge, a tunnel, surface type, directionality, lanes, speed limit and how to handle intersections.
name: Roads

subtypes.description: An unknown road is a road whose classification is unknown. Default to this preset when heads-up-digitizing without the necessary context to determine a road's classification.
subtypes.howToMap: Add an unknown road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Unknown Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Unknown Road

subtypes.description: A highway is a major highway, typically with at least two lanes separated by a centerline.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a highway by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Highway" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Highway

subtypes.description: A primary road is a major road, typically with at least two lanes separated by a centerline, forming a primary artery of the park and surrounding road network.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a primary road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Primary Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Primary Road

subtypes.description: A secondary road is a road that is not a segment of a major route but forms a link in the park and surrounding major road network. It typically has two lanes, separated by a centerline.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a secondary road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Secondary Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Secondary Road

subtypes.description: A minor road is a minor public road, typically at the lowest level of the interconnecting network. It is of lower importance than a secondary road and is not a residential street.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a minor road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Minor Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Minor Road

subtypes.description: A residential road is a road strictly intended for access within a residential area (community or neighborhood).
subtypes.howToMap: Add a residential road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Residential Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Residential Road

subtypes.description: An access road is a road accessing a service such as a parking lot, business park, service station, beach, campsite, etc.
subtypes.howToMap: Add an access road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Access Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Access Road

subtypes.description: A private road is the equivalent to what is commonly referred to as a "maintenance road" in the Park Service, with access limited to official NPS personnel and closed to the public.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a private road by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Private Road" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.name: Private Road

subtypes.description: A bridge is a structure used to carry a road, railway, or similar feature over another feature.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a bridge by splitting the upper way at each end of the bridge (where it joins solid ground) and selecting "Bridge" from the "Structure" form in the "Edit feature" menu. Remember to maintain the road's existing classification, e.g. "Primary Road."
subtypes.name: Bridge

subtypes.description: A tunnel is an underground or underwater passageway enclosed except for its entrance and exit at each end.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a tunnel by splitting the enclosed section of the way and selecting "Tunnel" from the "Structure" form in the "Edit feature" menu. Remember to maintain the road's existing classification, e.g. "Primary Road."
subtypes.name: Tunnel

subtypes.description: An intersection occurs where two or more ways (roads or trails) meet.
subtypes.howToMap: To create a simple intersection between two ways, remember to connect them with a node at the point of intersection. If one way is above another without forming a bridge or tunnel, such as a road interchange, do not connect the ways.
subtypes.name: Intersections

attributes.description: Surface describes the physical surface of a feature (in this case, a road or trail).
attributes.howToMap: Add a road's surface by selecting the associated way and choosing the appropriate surface type from the "Surface" form in the "Edit feature" menu:
attributes.name: Surface

attributes.description: One way indicates one way access restriction on roads.
attributes.howToMap: Add one way access by selecting the associated way and clicking "Assumed to be No" in the "One Way" form of the "Edit feature" menu, which will change to "Yes" after selection. Note that ways have a directionality, so the direction in which you map the way determines its directionality. However, you can change the {"oneway":"yes"} tag to {"oneway":"-1"} in the "All tags" table of the "Edit feature" menu to reverse its existing directionality (appropriate when a way's directionality already governs another attribute such as a bus route).
attributes.name: One Way

attributes.description: Lanes indicate the number of traffic lanes on a highway that are available to motorized traffic (bicycle lanes are therefore excluded).
attributes.howToMap: Add the number of lanes a road has by selecting the associated way and entering the appropriate number into the "Lanes" form of the "Edit feature" menu:
attributes.name: Lanes

attributes.description: Speed limit indicates the maximum legal speed limit for general traffic on a road.
attributes.howToMap: Add a road's speed limit by selecting the associated way and entering the appropriate number into the "Speed Limit" form of the "Edit feature" menu, along with the appropriate unit of measure (mph is the default).
attributes.name: Speed Limit

description: Generally speaking, a trail is intended primarily for recreational use such as walking, hiking, biking, skiing, etc.
howToMap: Add a trail by using the "Line" tool to trace its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu. If a trail's classification is unknown, default to the "Non-Motorized Trail" preset. Remember to add a trailhead to the start of each trail, along with the associated approved uses. If a trail crosses a road, forming a crosswalk, use the "Structure" form in the "Edit feature" menu to add the associated way as a "Crosswalk" (see the sidewalk section for more information).
featureTypes:
The presets for different trail types will vary, classified below.

Trails are a priority feature type for the NPS.gov Centennial redesign and will drive a "Trails" page for every park.
name: Trails

subtypes.description: A non-motorized trail is intended for non-motorized traffic including pedestrian use ("foot traffic"), biking, or horseback riding.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a non-motorized trail by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Non-Motorized Trail" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.approvedUsesDescription: If the trail is intended for specific uses, add the appropriate "Approved Use" using the "Approved Uses" form in the "Edit feature" menu:
subtypes.name: Non-Motorized Trail

subtypes.description: A motorized track is permissive to motorized traffic, such as all-terrain and four-wheel drive vehicles, motorcycles, and snowmobiles. A motorized track can be permissive to non-motorized traffic as well, but it must be permissive to motorized traffic to warrant this classification.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a motorized track by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Motorized Track" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.approvedUsesDescription: If the trail is intended for specific uses, add the appropriate "Approved Use" using the "Approved Uses" form in the "Edit feature" menu:
subtypes.name: Motorized Track

subtypes.description: A piste is a trail intended for winter sports such as downhill and cross-country skiing, dog sledding, and snowshoeing.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a piste by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu. Note: the "Places Editor Preview" features a downhill ski trail, one of many piste types below.
subtypes.furtherDescription:
• (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Difficulty=
  • Operator=
  • Track Type
  • Surface
  • Width (Meters)
  • Incline
  • Mountain Biking Difficulty
  • Hiking Difficulty
  • Trail Visibility
  • Approved Uses
  • (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Difficulty
  • Operator
  • Track Type
  • Surface
  • Width (Meters)
  • Incline
  • Mountain Biking Difficulty
  • Mountain Biking Uphill Difficulty
  • IMBA Trail Difficulty
  • Hiking Difficulty
  • Trail Visibility
  • Approved Uses
  • (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Difficulty
  • Operator
  • Track Type
  • Surface
  • Width (Meters)
  • Incline
  • Mountain Biking Difficulty
  • Mountain Biking Uphill Difficulty
  • IMBA Trail Difficulty
  • Hiking Difficulty
  • Trail Visibility
  • Approved Uses
  • (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Difficulty
  • Operator
  • Track Type
  • Surface
  • Width (Meters)
  • Incline
  • Mountain Biking Difficulty
  • Mountain Biking Uphill Difficulty
  • IMBA Trail Difficulty
  • Hiking Difficulty
  • Trail Visibility
  • Approved Uses
  • (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Difficulty
  • Operator
  • Track Type
  • Surface
  • Width (Meters)
  • Incline
  • Mountain Biking Difficulty
  • Mountain Biking Uphill Difficulty
  • IMBA Trail Difficulty
  • Hiking Difficulty
  • Trail Visibility
  • Approved Uses

A piste can also be added as a POI, using the "Point" tool to create a point and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu.
subtypes.name: Piste

subtypes.description: A water trail is a trail running through a waterway, intended for canoes, kayaks, motorboats, etc. Places supports two types of water trails: "Non-Motorized Watercraft Trail," for a route accessible to non-motorized watercraft such as a canoe or kayak, and "Motorized Watercraft Trail," for a route accessible to motorized watercraft such as a powerboat or motorized sailboat.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a water trail by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting the appropriate preset from the "Select feature type" menu. Note: the "Places Editor Preview" features a motorized watercraft trail.
subtypes.furtherDescription:
• (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Operator
  • Width (Meters)
  • (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Operator
  • Width (Meters)

The start and end of a water trail is often a boat launch, which is added as a POI (see the boat launch section for more information).
subtypes.name: Water Trail

description: Parking takes two primary forms in Places: parking lots and parking aisles.
howToMap: Add parking by using the "Area," "Point," and/or "Line" tool, depending on the feature type (described below).
featureTypes: Places supports the following parking types:
name: Parking

subtypes.description: A parking lot is a facility available for use by the public, customers, or other authorized users for the parking of motor vehicles (cars, trucks, motorcycles, etc). This can come in various forms, including a standalone parking lot or garage, among others.
subtypes.howToMap: Adding a parking lot is generally a two-step process. First, trace the area footprint and select "Parking" from the "Select feature type" menu:
subtypes.furtherDescription:
• (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Operator
  • Address
  • Capacity
  • Fee
  • Approved Uses

Next, create a point in the center of the area and select "Parking" from the "Select feature type" menu to add it as a POI. If electric vehicle parking is available, create another point in the center of the area and select "Electric Vehicle Parking" from the "Select feature type" menu as another POI. If the parking area is undefined simply add the point(s) without defining an area.

  • (Optionally) add these fields:
  • Name
  • Operator
  • Address
  • Capacity
  • Fee
  • Approved Uses
subtypes.name: Parking Lot

subtypes.description: A parking aisle is a subordinated way in a parking lot between rows of parking spaces that vehicles use to drive into and out of the spaces.
subtypes.howToMap: Add a parking aisle by tracing its centerline from beginning to end and selecting "Parking Aisle" from the "Select feature type" menu. The main way(s) in the parking lot, for entering and connecting multiple parking aisles, should be tagged as service roads.
subtypes.name: Parking Aisle
